page.title: 02CROFTING IN EDINBURGH
page.content: There are thirteen crofts being worked at present, but they do not produce enough to support a family. Black-faced sheep, cheriots and crosses are raised, their number controlled so that limited pasture is not over-grazed. The sale of lambs and wool barley compensates for the cost of winter feeding. Some crofters keep one or two cows and there is a small herd of highland cattle; all free of TB and brucellois. A few goats, hill ponies and hens are also reared. Some land is cultivated, producing potatoes, turnips and sometimes oats. Grass can be cut for hay, but even in good years, hay has to be bought from central Scotland. Animals are sold at markets in Portree or Dingwall. Some hogs are sent to over-winter on the mainland.
